title: China Eximbank provides $6.4 million export seller's credit to CWE for Volta Lake Resettlement Township Electrification Sub-Project of the Upper West Electrification Project (linked to #1243)
description: On March 2, 2000, the Government of Ghana signed a supplier credit agreement worth approximately $29.5 million with China International Water & Electric Corporation (CWE) for the Volta Lake Resettlement Township Electrification Sub-Project of the Upper West Electrification Project. The CWE supplier credit was provided through an RMB-denominated tranche (RMB 162 million) and a USD-denominated tranche ($6.4 million). Both tranches carried the following terms: 2% interest rate, 10 year maturity, and a 3 year grace period. This project entry captures the USD-denominated loan and project #1243 captures the RMB-denominated loan. The proceeds from both loan tranches were used to finance the extension of electricity to 106 townships (in Brong Ahafo Region, Eastern Region, Northern Region, and Volta Region) under the Volta Lake Resettlement Scheme.   In order to finance its supplier credit agreement with the Government of Ghana, CWE secured an export seller’s credit on September 8, 2000 from China Eximbank with an 11 year maturity. The loan terms captured in this project entry, however, are those of the supplier credit from CWE to Ghana.  Feasibility studies identified a total of 171 townships along the Volta Lake to benefit from the project, but due to the large number of towns involved, the project was carried out in phases. The first phase, which involved the electrification of 106 townships, had an estimated total cost of $32.8 million. CWE provided $29.5 million, covering approximately 90 percent of the total cost. The Government of Ghana was required to contribute the remaining 10% ($2.8 million dollars) as counterpart funding. CWE was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began in 2002 and ended in 203. However, the precise project completion date is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 的沃尔特湖移民村镇电气化项目. 2. Some media sources indicate that Ghana’s Parliament approved the supplier credit agreement in December 1999 rather than March 2000. However, the Government of Ghana’s Controller & Accountant General's Department records the loan commitment year as 2000.3.  In the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, it records a maturity of 11 years for this supplier credit but does not record an interest rate or grace period. AidData records the maturity (10 years), interest rate (2%), and grace period (3 years) reported at the time that Ghana’s Parliament approved the supplier credit. The 11-year maturity recorded by SAIS-CARI appears to refer to the term of the export seller’s credit that CWE secured from China Eximbank rather than the term of the supplier credit that CWE provided to the Government of Ghana.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $6.4 million export seller's credit to CWE for Volta Lake Resettlement Township Electrification Sub-Project of the Upper West Electrification Project (linked to #1243)

# Description
On March 2, 2000, the Government of Ghana signed a supplier credit agreement worth approximately $29.5 million with China International Water & Electric Corporation (CWE) for the Volta Lake Resettlement Township Electrification Sub-Project of the Upper West Electrification Project. The CWE supplier credit was provided through an RMB-denominated tranche (RMB 162 million) and a USD-denominated tranche ($6.4 million). Both tranches carried the following terms: 2% interest rate, 10 year maturity, and a 3 year grace period. This project entry captures the USD-denominated loan and project #1243 captures the RMB-denominated loan. The proceeds from both loan tranches were used to finance the extension of electricity to 106 townships (in Brong Ahafo Region, Eastern Region, Northern Region, and Volta Region) under the Volta Lake Resettlement Scheme.   In order to finance its supplier credit agreement with the Government of Ghana, CWE secured an export seller’s credit on September 8, 2000 from China Eximbank with an 11 year maturity. The loan terms captured in this project entry, however, are those of the supplier credit from CWE to Ghana.  Feasibility studies identified a total of 171 townships along the Volta Lake to benefit from the project, but due to the large number of towns involved, the project was carried out in phases. The first phase, which involved the electrification of 106 townships, had an estimated total cost of $32.8 million. CWE provided $29.5 million, covering approximately 90 percent of the total cost. The Government of Ghana was required to contribute the remaining 10% ($2.8 million dollars) as counterpart funding. CWE was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began in 2002 and ended in 203. However, the precise project completion date is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on electricity grid extension without specifying energy source, making its environmental impact dependent on the grid's energy mix
evidence: Extension of electricity to 106 townships, grid infrastructure development

title: Chinese Government dispatches 17th medical team to Ignace Deen Hospital, Labé Regional Hospital, and National Institute for Drug Quality Inspection
description: The Chinese Government has sent the Republic of Guinea 26 medical teams since 1968. On March 3, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Republic of Guinea signed a protocol agreement dispatching the 17th medical team to Guinea. The 17th medical team consisted of 16 experts from the Beijing Municipal Bureau of Health who were stationed at Ignace Deen Hospital (科纳克里伊涅斯丁医院 or Hôpital Ignace Deen), Labé Regional Hospital (拉贝医 or Hôpital Régional de Labé), and the National Institute for Drug Quality Inspection (科纳克里药检所). The team completed its term of service between July 22, 2000 and September 2002.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 17th medical team to Ignace Deen Hospital, Labé Regional Hospital, and National Institute for Drug Quality Inspection

# Description
The Chinese Government has sent the Republic of Guinea 26 medical teams since 1968. On March 3, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Republic of Guinea signed a protocol agreement dispatching the 17th medical team to Guinea. The 17th medical team consisted of 16 experts from the Beijing Municipal Bureau of Health who were stationed at Ignace Deen Hospital (科纳克里伊涅斯丁医院 or Hôpital Ignace Deen), Labé Regional Hospital (拉贝医 or Hôpital Régional de Labé), and the National Institute for Drug Quality Inspection (科纳克里药检所). The team completed its term of service between July 22, 2000 and September 2002.
justification: Project involves medical assistance and healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Dispatch of medical team to hospitals and drug quality inspection institute, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government dispatches 8th medical team to Hospital Nacional Simão Mendes
description: Since the Government of Guinea-Bissau resumed diplomatic relations with the PRC in 1998, Sichuan Province has been sending medical teams to Guinea-Bissau every two years. On June 16, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guinea-Bissau signed a protocol agreement, dispatching the 8th Chinese medical team to Guinea-Bissau. The 18-member team was stationed at Hospital Nacional Simão Mendes in Bissau. The team completed its term of service between 2000 and 2002.
staff_comments: This project is completed, but the exact end date of the project is unknown.
combined_text:

On June 16, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guinea-Bissau signed a protocol agreement, dispatching the 8th Chinese medical team to Guinea-Bissau. The 18-member team was stationed at Hospital Nacional Simão Mendes in Bissau. The team completed its term of service between 2000 and 2002.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment to hospital, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government send additional doctors to 4th medical team in Guyana
description: On January 6, 2000, the Chinese Government signed an exchange of letters committing five additional specialist doctors (one each for anesthesiology, ophthalmology, pathology, radiology, and pediatrics) to the 4th medical team in Guyana. The anesthesiologist, ophthalmologist, pathologist and radiologist would work at Georgetown Hospital, and the pediatrician would work at Lyndon Hospital between August 2000 and August 2002.
combined_text:

# Description

The anesthesiologist, ophthalmologist, pathologist and radiologist would work at Georgetown Hospital, and the pediatrician would work at Lyndon Hospital between August 2000 and August 2002.
justification: Project involves sending medical professionals to support healthcare services, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Specialist doctors sent to hospitals in Guyana for healthcare services

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.1 billion seller’s credit for 2x325MW Shazand Power Plant Project
description: On December 20, 2000, China Eximbank issued an RMB 1.1 billion seller’s credit to China Machinery Equipment Import and Export Corporation and the Shanghai Electric Group for 1.1 billion RMB for the 2x325MW Shazand Power Plant Project. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a contract that was signed with China Machinery Equipment Import and Export Corporation and the Shanghai Electric Group in June 1996.   The Chinese contractors were responsible for designing a power plant in the city of Shazahand within Iranian Azerbaijan (Shazand County, Markazi Province) with two 325,000 kilowatt generating units. They were also responsible for engineering management, civil engineering, and equipment installation (including boilers, steam turbines, generating sets, meter control systems and electricity systems). The originally expected project completion date was March 20, 2004. This first power generation unit was commissioned in 2004 and the second power generation unit was commissioned in 2005.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 伊朗Sahand热电站, 2×325MW. The Persian project title is نیروگاه شازند.
combined_text:

# Description

The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a contract that was signed with China Machinery Equipment Import and Export Corporation and the Shanghai Electric Group in June 1996.   The Chinese contractors were responsible for designing a power plant in the city of Shazahand within Iranian Azerbaijan (Shazand County, Markazi Province) with two 325,000 kilowatt generating units. justification: Project involves construction of a large-scale coal-fired power plant
evidence: 2x325MW power plant with boilers and steam turbines, typical of coal-fired facilities

title: China Eximbank provides $8.5 million buyer’s credit loan for Iran's Bank of Industry and Mine to produce sodium carbonate used in glass manufacturing
description: In January 2000, China Eximbank issued a $8.5 million buyer’s credit loan to Iran’s Bank of Industry and Mine — an Iranian government-owned bank — for the production of sodium carbonate used in glass manufacturing. This loan is fully disbursed. Iran subsequently imported $8 million worth of sodium carbonate from China, but once the sodium carbonate was imported, Iran became self-sufficient in production.
staff_comments: 1. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $8.5 million buyer’s credit loan for Iran's Bank of Industry and Mine to produce sodium carbonate used in glass manufacturing

# Description
In January 2000, China Eximbank issued a $8.5 million buyer’s credit loan to Iran’s Bank of Industry and Mine — an Iranian government-owned bank — for the production of sodium carbonate used in glass manufacturing. This loan is fully disbursed. Iran subsequently imported $8 million worth of sodium carbonate from China, but once the sodium carbonate was imported, Iran became self-sufficient in production.
justification: Project focuses on industrial chemical production for glass manufacturing, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Production of sodium carbonate for glass manufacturing, no energy transition or environmental impact mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides $20.8 million buyer's credit loan for Phase 2 of Khatoonabad Copper Smelter Project
description: On September 7, 2000, China Eximbank and the Bank Tejarat of Iran signed a $20,840,000 buyer’s credit loan for Phase 2 of Khatoonabad Copper Smelter Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds of this loan were used to finance 85% of the cost of a $24.5 million commercial contract with China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction Company Limited. This project involved the construction of the Khatoonabad Copper Smelter in the town of Khatoonabad (or Khatoon Abad) within Kerman province, which is located at 30.080 N and 55.400 E with an attitude of 1780 meters above sea level. The furnace was ignited for the first time on April 26, 2004 and copper production began on July 26, 2004. A formal project completion ceremony took place on December 21, 2004. The plant successfully passed a performance assessment on June 20, 2005.  Phase 1 of the project started in 1993. China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction company signed a design and supply contract that worthed $609,500,00 with National Iranian Copper Industry Co. on November 24, 1993. China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction company agreed to provided design, equipment, installation and adjustment service, and training to Khatoonabad Copper Smelter Project.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as Phase II of the Khatoon Abad Copper Smelter Plant Construction Project, Phase II of the Khatunabad Copper Complex Construction project, Phase II of the Copper Smelter Plant Construction Project, or Khatoon Abad Copper Smelter Project. The Chinese project title is 阿巴德铜冶炼厂 or 伊朗哈通-阿巴德銅冶煉廠項目 or 伊朗哈通•阿巴德铜冶炼厂项目. The Persian project title is کارخانه ذوب مس خاتون آباد. 2. The Government of Iran holds a minority ownership stake in Bank Tejarat. 3. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $20.8 million buyer's credit loan for Phase 2 of Khatoonabad Copper Smelter Project

# Description
On September 7, 2000, China Eximbank and the Bank Tejarat of Iran signed a $20,840,000 buyer’s credit loan for Phase 2 of Khatoonabad Copper Smelter Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds of this loan were used to finance 85% of the cost of a $24.5 million commercial contract with China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction Company Limited. This project involved the construction of the Khatoonabad Copper Smelter in the town of Khatoonabad (or Khatoon Abad) within Kerman province, which is located at 30.080 N and 55.400 E with an attitude of 1780 meters above sea level. The furnace was ignited for the first time on April 26, 2004 and copper production began on July 26, 2004. A formal project completion ceremony took place on December 21, 2004. The plant successfully passed a performance assessment on June 20, 2005.  Phase 1 of the project started in 1993. China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction company signed a design and supply contract that worthed $609,500,00 with National Iranian Copper Industry Co. on November 24, 1993. China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction company agreed to provided design, equipment, installation and adjustment service, and training to Khatoonabad Copper Smelter Project.
justification: Project focuses on copper smelting, a critical mineral for energy transition technologies
evidence: Copper smelter construction, copper production, energy transition mineral processing

title: Chinese Government donates a shipment of humanitarian aid
description: On December 22, 2000, in apparent defiance of the United Nations embargo on air travel to Iraq, an Air China Limited plane — carrying a 69-member government delegation and a shipment of humanitarian aid — arrived at Saddam International Airport in Baghdad, Iraq. The delegation, led by  State Councilor Ismail Amat, included ministry officials from foreign affairs, health, and foreign trade and economic cooperation officials, accompanied by members of the Red Cross Society of China. The exact monetary value of this donation, as well as the composition of the humanitarian materials, is unknown. The Air China flight was the the first Chinese aircraft to land in Iraq since the U.N. imposed sanctions against Iraq in 1990 following its invasion of Kuwait.
combined_text:

The delegation, led by  State Councilor Ismail Amat, included ministry officials from foreign affairs, health, and foreign trade and economic cooperation officials, accompanied by members of the Red Cross Society of China. The exact monetary value of this donation, as well as the composition of the humanitarian materials, is unknown. justification: Humanitarian aid shipment with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Shipment of humanitarian aid, no specific energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese government donated 320 Computers to Jamaican Ministry of Education
description: Between the 19th and 21st of November in 2000, the Chinese government donated 320 computers to the Ministry of Education and Culture of Jamaica. The Chinese Minister of Education, Chen Zhili, attended the donation ceremony.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 100 million government concessional loan for the Second Phase of Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#69263)
description: On April 14, 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Government of Jamaica signed a RMB 100 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Second Phase of the Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation Project. According to internal records that Jamaica’s Ministry of Finance and the Public Service supplied to AidData in May 2020, the loan carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity period of 10.25 years, a grace period of 4.75 years, an interest rate of 4%, a commitment fee of 0.50%, and a management fee of 0.25%. The first scheduled date of loan repayment was January 1, 2005 and the final date of scheduled loan repayment was July 10, 2010. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to acquire equipment and supplies to support the implementation of the Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation Project. As of October 30, 2021, the loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate (RMB 100 million out of RMB 100 million). Its outstanding amount was zero as of October 30, 2021.   China National Corporation for Overseas Economic Cooperation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Given that the loan fully disbursed and China Eximbank funded a subsequent phase of the same project, AidData has assumed that the project reached completion (although the precise date of completion is unknown).
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Second Phase of the Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation & Extension Project. 2. The China Eximbank-financed Third Phase of the Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation & Extension is captured in Project ID#69263. 3. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the China-Latin America Finance Database, co-produced by the Inter-American Dialogue and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 100 million government concessional loan for the Second Phase of Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#69263)

# Description
On April 14, 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Government of Jamaica signed a RMB 100 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Second Phase of the Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation Project. According to internal records that Jamaica’s Ministry of Finance and the Public Service supplied to AidData in May 2020, the loan carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity period of 10.25 years, a grace period of 4.75 years, an interest rate of 4%, a commitment fee of 0.50%, and a management fee of 0.25%. The first scheduled date of loan repayment was January 1, 2005 and the final date of scheduled loan repayment was July 10, 2010. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to acquire equipment and supplies to support the implementation of the Jamaica Water System Rehabilitation Project. As of October 30, 2021, the loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate (RMB 100 million out of RMB 100 million). Its outstanding amount was zero as of October 30, 2021.   China National Corporation for Overseas Economic Cooperation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Given that the loan fully disbursed and China Eximbank funded a subsequent phase of the same project, AidData has assumed that the project reached completion (although the precise date of completion is unknown).
justification: Water system rehabilitation project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Water supply and sanitation sector, focus on water system rehabilitation and equipment acquisition
